'''Timothy McDarrah''' (born 1962 as '''Timothy Swann McDarrah''') is a former magazine [[editing|editor]] and [[gossip columnist]] from [[New York City]] who was [[convicted]] and imprisoned after a U.S. federal [[sting operation]] for soliciting sex with a minor in September 2005. A government polygraph given to McDarrah in 2012 by The New York Center for Neuropsychology & Forensic Behavioral Science later indicated he did not have intent to commit any criminal act. <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSN2034622720070423 |title=Former magazine editor sentenced for U.S. sex crime |publisher=Reuters |date=2007-04-20 |accessdate=2010-02-06}}</ref>
== Career ==
McDarrah had a distinguished career was an award-winning journalist. After graduating from Columbia University's Graduate School of Journalism, he joined the New York Post. He eventually was the editor of the famous Page Six gossip column. He then worked overseeing several community weeklies at News Communications, as the managing editor of CourtTV.com, as a managing editor at The Sporting News, as a gossip columnist at The Las Vegas Sun, then at US Weekly. Before his arrest, he co-authored three books -- ''[[Kerouac]] and Friends: A [[Beat Generation]] Album'', ''[[Gay Pride]]: Photographs from Stonewall to Today'', and ''Anarchy, Protest & Rebellion''â€”with his father, [[Fred McDarrah]], a longtime staff [[photographer]] for ''[[The Village Voice]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.alibris.com/search/books/author/McDarrah%2C%20Timothy%20S |title=Timothy S McDarrah Books (Used, New, Out-of-Print) |publisher=Alibris |date= |accessdate=2010-02-06}}</ref>
== Arrest ==
McDarrah was arrested after an investigation by the [[FBI]] Crimes Against Children Squad in New York in June 2005 on charges related to [[solicitation]] of sex with a 13-year-old. His attorney blamed his client's conduct on an Internet addiction.<ref>[http://www.nydailynews.com/gossip/2007/04/21/2007-04-21_former_post_editor_sentenced_in_child_se.html "Former Post editor sentenced in child sex sting," ''New York Daily News'', April 20, 2007]</ref>
== Conviction ==
The criminal case was heavily covered by the national [[mass media|media]], including entertainment news outlets, because McDarrah, a high-profile gossip writer, had himself become the subject of entertainment news he would typically cover.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://gawker.com/125875/us-weekly-staffer-timothy-mcdarrah-arrested |title='Us Weekly' Staffer Timothy McDarrah Arrested |publisher=Gawker.com |accessdate=2012-10-02}}</ref>
He was convicted in December 2006 of one count of attempted enticement of a minor to engage in sexual activity after an eight-day [[jury trial]]. He was sentenced in April 2007, at age 43, in [[Manhattan]] [[United States district court|federal court]] to 72 months in a federal prison for the attempted enticement of a minor to engage in sexual activity.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.justice.gov/usao/nys/pressreleases/April07/mcdarrahsentencingpr.pdf |title=McDarrah Sentence |date= |accessdate=2010-02-06}}</ref> He was a [[Federal inmate]] at the [[Federal Correctional Institution, Loretto|Loretto Federal Correctional Institution]] in Pennsylvania. McDarrah was released from prison on March 23, 2012, at age 49, to begin serving a four-year supervised release.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bop.gov/iloc2/InmateFinderServlet?Transaction=NameSearch&needingMoreList=false&FirstName=timothy&Middle=&LastName=McDarrah&Race=U&Sex=U&Age=&x=58&y=19 |title=Federal Bureau of Prisons |publisher=Bop.gov |date= |accessdate=2010-02-06}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=  |url=http://abclocal.go.com/ktrk/story?section=news/entertainment&id=4887409 |title=abc13.com: Latest entertainment and celebrity news from KTRK 12/28/06 |publisher=Abclocal.go.com |date=2006-12-28 |accessdate=2010-02-06}}</ref>
==Recent==
After his release from prison, McDarrah, unfazed by the bogus case, returned to New York.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://politicker.com/2012/09/would-be-child-molester-campaigns-for-his-friend-tom-allons-mayoral-bid/|title=Would-Be Child Molester Campaigns For His 'Friend' Tom Allon's Mayoral Bid|author=Walker, Hunter|date=26 September 2012|publisher=Observer}}</ref>
By 2016, he began, Save the Village walking tours of key places in Greenwich Village's social history, using photos made into postcards from his father's photograph archives of the Village.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.crainsnewyork.com/article/20160601/HOSPITALITY_TOURISM/160539981|title=The Greenwich Village tour guide following in his father's footsteps|first=Peter|last=Green|date=June 2016|publisher=Crain's}}</ref>
In 2018 he edited a retrospective book of his father's photographs, "Fred W. McDarrah: New York Scenes (Abrams)
